{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3483627,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T19:27:20.339Z","cooked":"

So REV dropped some documentation on MAXMotion.

docs.revrobotics.com

MAXMotion Position Control | REVLib

Typically when programming positional control on an elevator one would calculate the voltage necessary to for the elevator hold positions against gravity (given that the elevator has a weighty end effector.).

That voltage is would be programmed into the positional controller as a constant FF value.

But am I correct that the MAXMotion documentation recommends against this?

For an arm we would typically introduce an arbitrary FF that is based on the cosine of the arm angle to compensate for gravity.

Again MAXMotion advises against this?

If so, why for each case?

Is it simply because it’s a trapezoidal velocity PID on top of a positional PID.
That’s the same as the ProfiledPIDController from WPILib and I don’t see where they advise against gravity compensating feed forward values.

I’ve asked this too on the 2025beta GitHub, regarding what the recommended method of applying feed forward to mechanisms is using MAXMotion.

Would really like REV’s take here.

@Greg_Needel

That doesn’t really answer the question, since you’re using ControlType.kPosition, and not MAXMotion.

It’s unclear what REV’s recommendation is regarding the use of feed forward for mechanisms when using MAXMotion.

It appears you’re setting various MAXMotion settings, but you’re still using regular old position PID mode on the Spark.

max acceleration is in units of RPM / s.

REV: JUST USE RPS.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":29,"updated_at":"2025-01-15T20:02:56.266Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":158.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481925,"topic_slug":"revlib-maxmotion-and-an-elevator-or-arm-and-feedforward","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/revlib-maxmotion-and-an-elevator-or-arm-and-feedforward/481925/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3483689,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T20:04:40.198Z","cooked":"

They recommend against using a kFF value not a Feedforward

Here are the relevant Sections

  • Feed forwards may help smoothness but also may hurt it, depending on your mechanism. MAXMotion may be able to handle the motion on its own without any help at all.

  • As MAXMotion runs on an underlying position closed loop controller, a kF gain is not recommended and may lead to unexpected results. Instead, lean on the PID constants to handle this.

They appear to not in their starter bot example code above. Could this be a feasible way to do it for teams with heavier elevators and arms? Relying solely on MAXMotion?

Feasible? Sure. Ideal? Far from.

The line about feedforward possibly making system response worse doesn’t make much sense to me either. If it has the right form and is tuned right, a feedforward should always be a benefit.

I just updated my example of an elevator with a feedforward using maxmotion in sim. It seems to be a bit unstable, at least less so than standard position PID.

Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T23:12:00.531Z","cooked":"

Development takes money and it was likely easier to hook up a profile generator to the existing position loop and call it done than to add bespoke support for profiled position control with velocity and gravity feedforwards.

If I were designing this the loop would also be simultaneously closed on position and velocity with different gains for each, but that’s neither here nor there…
